{"comments": {"id": 26757, "count": 46, "talk_id": 2139}, "threadId": 26757, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "2139", "description": "Worldwide, violence is on the decline, but in the crowded cities of the global south — cities like Aleppo, Bamako and Caracas — violence is actually accelerating, fueled by the drug trade, mass unemployment and civil unrest. Security researcher Robert Muggah turns our attention toward these "fragile cities," super-fast-growing places where infrastructure is weak and government often ineffective. He shows us the four big risks we face, and offers a way to change course.", "event": "TEDGlobal 2014", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Robert Muggah: How to protect fast-growing cities from failing", "slug": "robert_muggah_how_to_protect_fast_growing_cities_from_failing", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "2049", "slug": "robert_muggah", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Robert", "lastname": "Muggah", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Megacities expert", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/7e99d8cc296eb83eb69976171a9e170ee0ff970f_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Megacities are going to influence norms, processes and revolutionize governance at a scale hitherto unimagined.", "whotheyare": "Robert Muggah creates tools to understand cycles of violence in urban environments and opens dialogues on ways to confront them globally.", "whylisten": "

Robert Muggah drills down through shadowy data on arms trafficking, urban violence and resilience in search of answers for a rapidly urbanizing society’s most troubling questions: Why are cities so violent, and increasingly fragile? Why are conflicts within nations replacing conflicts between them? And what strategies can we implement to reduce violence?

Muggah's high-tech toolkit includes new ways for citizens to collect, collate and understand data, such as the mapping arms data (MAD) tool. As the research director of the Igarapé Institute and the SecDev Foundation, he developed the tool in collaboration with the Peace Research Institute Oslo and with Google Ideas, winning accolades for the transparency it brings to the debate.

"https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/7e99d8cc296eb83eb69976171a9e170ee0ff970f_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Megacities are going to influence norms, processes and revolutionize governance at a scale hitherto unimagined.", "whotheyare": "Robert Muggah creates tools to understand cycles of violence in urban environments and opens dialogues on ways to confront them globally.", "whylisten": "

Robert Muggah drills down through shadowy data on arms trafficking, urban violence and resilience in search of answers for a rapidly urbanizing society’s most troubling questions: Why are cities so violent, and increasingly fragile? Why are conflicts within nations replacing conflicts between them? And what strategies can we implement to reduce violence?

Muggah's high-tech toolkit includes new ways for citizens to collect, collate and understand data, such as the mapping arms data (MAD) tool. As the research director of the Igarapé Institute and the SecDev Foundation, he developed the tool in collaboration with the Peace Research Institute Oslo and with Google Ideas, winning accolades for the transparency it brings to the debate.

"}], "speaker_name": "Robert Muggah", "tags": ["cities", "global issues", "violence", "war", "youth", "infrastructure"], "title": "How to protect fast-growing cities from failing", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 968585}]}
